qas.question: Tumors that are able to evade the body's immune response can become what?
What receptors do tumor cells often have reduced concentrations of?
What is a chemical secreted by tumors that suppresses the immune response?
Cytokine TBF-B suppresses the activity of what cell types?
What is unable to evade the immune system?

plausible_answers.text: reduced number of MHC class I molecules

qas.question: What makes detection by killer T cells more likely?
What do tumor cells release that strengthens the immune response?
What does cytokine TGF-β encourage the activity of?

plausible_answers.text: immune system no longer attacks the tumor cells

qas.question: What happens when the immune system loses tolerance for tumor antigens?

context: Clearly, <b4_0>some tumors<b4_0/> evade the immune system and go on to become <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>cancers<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>. Tumor cells often have a <b5_0>reduced number of <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>MHC class I<a1_1/> molecules<b5_0/><a1_2/><a1_0/> on their surface, thus avoiding detection by killer T cells. Some tumor cells also release products that inhibit the immune response; for example by secreting the <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b6_0>cytokine TGF-β<b6_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, which suppresses the activity of <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b7_0>macrophages and lymphocytes<b7_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>. In addition, immunological tolerance may develop against tumor antigens, so the <b8_0>immune system no longer attacks the tumor cells<b8_0/>.
